data.title: Sainte Amélie, La Chapelle Royale, Saint-Ferdinand, Paris France
data.meta_description:
The Saint-Ferdinand chapel, (now the Church of Our Lady of Compassion)was built in 1843 according to plans by the king's architect Pierre-François-Léonard Fontaine, on the site of the house where, on the 13th July 1842 prince Ferdinand-Philippe d'Orleans, eldest son of King Louis-Philippe, died following a carriage accident.
	Prince Ferdinand had left the Tuileries in his carriage drawn by two horses, to meet his parents in Neuilly before heading to Saint-Omer to inspect his regiment. 
	At the end of the road at Ternes he ordered the coachman to change direction, the horses reared, then bolted;  the Duke jumped on to the road but fell so violently that he fractured his skull. He was carried into the back room of the store Cordier, at 4 rue Revolt, there, the heir to the throne, aged 32, died a few hours later in the presence of the royal family. 
	His body was transferred to the vaults of the Royal Chapel of Dreux, the necropolis of the Orleans Royal Family and a small chapel was built in 1842-1843 on the site of the house of the grocer.  (At the site of the current Palais des Congrès at Porte Maillot). 
	This chapel - then called the Chapel of Saint-Ferdinand, was built in the shape of a cross in the neo-Byzantine style, reminiscent of ancient tombs. 
	During the construction of the convention centre at Porte Maillot in 1964 the building was moved a few hundred meters and rebuilt stone by stone at 25 Pershing Boulevard on the Place du Général Koenig (Porte des Ternes).

Prince Ferdinand had left the Tuileries in his carriage drawn by two horses, to meet his parents in Neuilly before heading to Saint-Omer to inspect his regiment.

At the end of the road at Ternes he ordered the coachman to change direction, the horses reared, then bolted; the Duke jumped on to the road but fell so violently that he fractured his skull. He was carried into the back room of the store Cordier, at 4 rue Revolt, there, the heir to the throne, aged 32, died a few hours later in the presence of the royal family.

His body was transferred to the vaults of the Royal Chapel of Dreux, the necropolis of the Orleans Royal Family and a small chapel was built in 1842-1843 on the site of the house of the grocer. (At the site of the current Palais des Congrès at Porte Maillot).

This chapel - then called the Chapel of Saint-Ferdinand, was built in the shape of a cross in the neo-Byzantine style, reminiscent of ancient tombs.

During the construction of the convention centre at Porte Maillot in 1964 the building was moved a few hundred meters and rebuilt stone by stone at 25 Pershing Boulevard on the Place du Général Koenig (Porte des Ternes).
